Full Paragraph Text: Strong growth continued in most other emerging markets, in particular the Philippines, South Asia, the Indochina region, Turkey and many markets in Africa. We introduced new premium noodles in Singapore and Malaysia. In the Philippines the new fortified Bear Brand milk powders were well received. Maggi created a new breakfast option for the Indian market, Maggi Oats Noodles, and Nestlé Milo Activ-Go was launched in parts of South East Asia. It was also rolled out in Africa, helping to deliver good growth across the continent.

Full Paragraph Text: Nestlé Waters delivered solid broad-based organic and real internal growth in all three geographies. Nestlé Pure Life continued to be a growth engine, particularly in the emerging markets but also in North America and the United Kingdom. Perrier and S.Pellegrino, our premium international brands, continued to demonstrate our ability to create value in the category. Complementing these performances, strong local brands also delivered good growth, especially Buxton in the United Kingdom, Erikli in Turkey, La Vie in Vietnam and Yunnan Shan Quan in China.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 Unilever launched a newly developed packaging technology for Dove Body Wash bottles that uses 15% less plastic. Projected cost savings for the whole portfolio are €50 million. This is another substantial step towards the USLP target of halving Unilever’s waste footprint by 2020.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company taking action by launching new packaging technology for its Dove product line.; Environmental and Societal: The environmental impact through plastic reduction, which affects waste footprint at a broader societal level.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's organizational decision to implement new packaging technology directly reduces plastic usage, contributing to a decreased environmental waste footprint.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as a company, is implementing a new packaging technology.; Environmental and Societal: The reduction in plastic usage contributes to Unilever's goal of reducing its waste footprint, impacting environmental sustainability.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's new packaging technology reduces plastic use, contributing to its waste reduction goals.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as an organization, is implementing a new packaging technology.; Environmental and Societal: The initiative aims to reduce waste and has broader implications for environmental sustainability.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's new packaging technology reduces plastic use, contributing to environmental sustainability.

Its actions (launching technology, setting USLP targets, achieving cost savings) are organizational-level activities.; Environmental and Societal: The reduction of plastic use and the target of halving Unilever’s waste footprint directly refer to the impact on natural systems and broader societal waste issues.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's new packaging technology, an organizational initiative, directly reduces plastic waste, impacting the environmental and societal scales.

Full Paragraph Text: The MuCell® Technology for Extrusion Blow Moulding was created in partnership with two packaging suppliers – ALPLA and MuCell Extrusion. By using gas-injection to create gas bubbles in the middle layer of the bottle wall, it reduces the density of the bottle and the amount of plastic required.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: The partnership between multiple organizations (ALPLA and MuCell Extrusion) to develop the MuCell® Technology represents inter-organizational collaboration.; Environmental and Societal: The reduction in plastic usage has a clear environmental impact by reducing resource consumption and potentially waste.
claude3.7: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] A partnership between packaging suppliers ALPLA and MuCell Extrusion created technology that reduces plastic usage, directly benefiting the environment through resource reduction.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: ALPLA and MuCell Extrusion are specific organizations involved in the technology development.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The partnership between ALPLA and MuCell Extrusion represents a collaboration across organizations within the packaging industry.

o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: The collaboration between multiple packaging suppliers indicates a sector-level interaction.; Organizational: The specific organizations involved, ALPLA and MuCell Extrusion, are directly engaged in the development of the technology.
o4_mini: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational] The partnership between ALPLA and MuCell Extrusion leads to the development of a new technology that reduces plastic use.

Full Paragraph Text: The technology represents a breakthrough for Unilever and the industry. With up to 59 million Dove Body Wash bottles sold across Europe, the new technology will save approximately 180 tonnes of plastic a year overall. A full roll-out across every Unilever product and packaging format could save up to 27,000 tonnes of plastic per year.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a specific company implementing the new technology in their Dove Body Wash bottles.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The industry as a whole that could be affected by this technology, with potential impact across the sector if fully implemented.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's breakthrough technology implementation in Dove products creates potential industry-wide impact that could save thousands of tonnes of plastic if adopted across the sector.

Full Paragraph Text: Tough economic and financial headwinds with continued competitive intensity made 2014 one of the most challenging years that the industry and Unilever have faced for some time. A slowdown in the growth of emerging markets proved a testing environment while consumers in developed markets continued to show caution. Volatile currencies were a further negative.

claude3.7: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] Macro-economic conditions including market slowdowns, consumer caution, and currency volatility directly impacted Unilever's business performance in 2014.

Full Paragraph Text: However, Unilever’s business model and strategy proved robust, delivering a competitive performance with underlying sales growth ahead of the market and solid margin expansion. Our growth model is based on a leaner, more agile Unilever and consistency of delivery in this more volatile market is key. The Boards remain convinced that a clear, purpose-driven business model is the best way for Unilever to continue generating sustainable, long-term returns for all stakeholders, including our shareholders, as proved by a year of strong, dependable cash flow and steadily increasing dividends. The full year dividend paid in 2014 rose to €1.12, a 7% increase on 2013.
claude3.7: Summary: N/A

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal <-> Organizational] A volatile market influences Unilever's need for agility and consistency, while Unilever's strong business model and cash flow generate returns and steadily increasing dividends for shareholders and stakeholders.

Full Paragraph Text: The key is to have a model that responds to people’s needs and concerns, and an organisation that is both resilient and agile in the face of growing economic and geopolitical uncertainty. We achieved that again in 2014 and I want to thank – and recognise – the supreme efforts of our 172,000 colleagues and the many more partners around the world.

Full Paragraph Text: Even though we have made significant strides over recent years in improving our organisational agility and our ability to respond quickly to events, there is still room for improvement. I would like to have seen us react a little quicker, for example, to the slowdown in a number of markets, particularly China, where frankly we were caught off-guard by the speed and scale of weakening consumer demand. In terms of our categories, all of them contributed – albeit in different ways – to the overall performance of the Group and I have confidence in the strength and long-term growth potential of our portfolio.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The organization being discussed ('we', 'our organizational agility', 'our ability to respond') is clearly a single company or formal entity.; Environmental and Societal: The 'slowdown in a number of markets, particularly China' and 'weakening consumer demand' represent macro-level market and societal conditions.
claude3.7: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] Weakening consumer demand in China and other markets directly impacted the organization's performance, catching them off-guard despite improved organizational agility.

4o: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] The weakening consumer demand in China impacted the organization's ability to respond quickly.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] A slowdown in markets and weakening consumer demand at the societal level caught the organization off-guard and impacted its ability to react.

Full Paragraph Text: We took steps last year to sharpen the portfolio even further with a number of strategic acquisitions and disposal of non-core brands, although there is always scope to do more and I would like to see the level of activity accelerate in the year ahead. It is also clear that we still need to do more to get our Foods category growing again, although we are winning market share.

Full Paragraph Text: This is a tough business to be in – with much of our portfolio in flat or even declining developed markets – but we have to do more to leverage the strength of our wonderful Foods brands and bring back the growth momentum. By contrast, while our Home Care and Refreshment categories delivered good or solid growth, we need to increase the levels of cash and profitability if we are to invest in the many growth opportunities. These will all be priorities in 2015.

Full Paragraph Text: There is no doubt that over the long term our investors have benefited from their continued belief in Unilever, with total shareholder return increasing by a further 18% in 2014. Our employees remain a key priority of course and, despite the constrained economic environment, we did not compromise on our investments in training, personal development, safety and other employee support programmes. It was heartening to see employee engagement scores remain at historically high levels in our annual Global People Survey (GPS), with improvements across all five metrics.

claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational <-> Individual] Unilever's organizational investments in employee programs positively affect individual employees (shown by high engagement scores), while individual investors benefit from their belief in the company through increased shareholder returns.

Full Paragraph Text: It is also clear that the demand to join Unilever has never been greater. We received over 2 million applications or expressions of interest in 2014 and for the second year running Unilever was ranked the third most in-demand employer among jobseekers on LinkedIn, behind only Apple and Google, as more and more young people want to work for purpose-driven organisations.

Full Paragraph Text: We also made progress in our commitment to serve a wider group of stakeholders through the USLP and our Vision of growing the business while reducing our environmental footprint and increasing our positive social impact, not only in that part of the business under our direct control but throughout the whole value chain. This manifests itself in many different ways – everything from playing our part in putting an end to deforestation to ensuring we embrace and advance human rights principles throughout the length of our supply chain. You can see a number of examples set out in other parts of this report.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] An organization commits to reducing its environmental footprint and increasing positive social impact by extending its efforts throughout its entire value chain to address issues like deforestation and human rights principles.

Full Paragraph Text: It was pleasing to see our efforts recognised once again in 2014, including regaining sector leadership in the prestigious Dow Jones Sustainability Index (DJSI) and being ranked – for the fourth year running – as the Number One Company in the Globescan/SustainAbility index of leading sustainability experts around the world.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('our efforts') is a single organization being evaluated and recognized.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The Dow Jones Sustainability Index (DJSI) and Globescan/SustainAbility index represent sector-level evaluation systems that compare multiple organizations.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] A single company's sustainability efforts influenced its ranking and recognition at the sector level through the DJSI and Globescan/SustainAbility indices.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The recognition pertains to a specific company being ranked and acknowledged.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The Dow Jones Sustainability Index and Globescan/SustainAbility index involve multiple organizations and sector-wide evaluations.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] A company's sustainability efforts lead to its recognition in sector-wide indices.
o4_mini: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The phrase 'our efforts' refers to the actions and performance of a specific organization (the entity speaking).; Environmental and Societal: The Dow Jones Sustainability Index (DJSI) and the Globescan/SustainAbility index, along with 'leading sustainability experts around the world,' represent broader societal and market-level evaluation systems and communities that assess organizational performance on a global scale.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] An organization's efforts led to its recognition and high ranking by global sustainability indices and experts.

Full Paragraph Text: A fundamental requirement at Unilever is to understand our consumers. We use focus groups and quantitative studies and spend time with consumers in stores and in their homes to find out what is important to them – as citizens as well as consumers – so we can create products they need and want. Unilever carelines are also a rich source of information. Digital communications and social media mean we can engage with large numbers of people consistently over long periods of time so we can immerse ourselves in their day-to-day lives. We can use online search data to identify and anticipate future consumer trends and gain a competitive edge.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers who provide information about their needs, preferences, and behaviors through focus groups, studies, home visits, carelines, and social media interactions.; Organizational: Unilever as a company that collects consumer data, analyzes it, and uses it to inform product development and gain competitive advantage.
claude3.7: Summary: [Individual <-> Organizational] Consumers provide information about their needs and preferences to Unilever, which the company then uses to create products that meet those needs, establishing a feedback loop between individual consumers and organizational strategy.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The focus is on understanding individual consumers and their behaviors.; Organizational: Unilever, as an organization, uses consumer insights to develop products.
4o: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational] Unilever uses consumer insights to develop products that meet consumer needs and preferences.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as a company, conducts research to understand consumer needs.; Individual: Consumers are engaged through focus groups and direct interactions to gather insights.; Environmental and Societal: Understanding consumers as citizens reflects societal-level considerations.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's research into consumer preferences influences product development while considering their societal roles.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'consumers', 'people', and 'citizens' whose needs, trends, and feedback (via focus groups, carelines, social media, search data) are gathered and analyzed.; Organizational: Refers to 'Unilever' and 'we' (Unilever) which actively collects data, engages with individuals, and uses this information to create products and gain a competitive edge.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Individual] Individual consumers provide data and insights to Unilever, which the organization then uses to create products that meet their needs, thereby continuing the cycle of interaction and information generation.

Full Paragraph Text: R&D is an engine of sustainable growth; Unilever spends around €1 billion on R&D annually. Our 6,000 R&D professionals are responsible for building brands through benefit-led innovation, which is unlocked through science and technology. This includes looking at long-term emerging science and transforming science into technologies which are used to design branded products.
claude3.7: Summary: N/A
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company is investing in R&D to drive growth.; Individual: The 6,000 R&D professionals are individuals contributing to the company's innovation efforts.
4o: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational] R&D professionals at Unilever drive the company's brand innovation through science and technology.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as a single organization, invests heavily in R&D to drive growth.; Individual: The 6,000 R&D professionals represent individuals whose work contributes to innovation.; Environmental and Societal: The focus on sustainable growth and emerging science indicates a broader impact on societal and environmental systems.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's investment in R&D empowers its professionals to innovate, which contributes to sustainable growth impacting society and the environment.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is explicitly named as a company, representing a single organization. Its activities like 'spends around €1 billion on R&D annually' and 'building brands' are actions taken at the organizational level.; Individual: The '6,000 R&D professionals' refer to specific individuals (employees) who carry out the work described, acting as the agents of innovation within the organization.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational <-> Individual] Unilever (Organizational) invests in R&D, enabling its professionals (Individual) to drive innovation and build brands, which in turn benefits the organization.

Full Paragraph Text: To meet our Vision we know we must work in partnership with others, such as suppliers, agencies, universities, governments and NGOs.

Additionally, 'suppliers', 'agencies', 'universities', and 'NGOs' are examples of other single organizations or formal groups that the speaker's organization intends to partner with.; Environmental and Societal: 'Governments' are explicitly mentioned as societal-level systems with which the organization plans to partner.

Full Paragraph Text: The big development for 2014 has been the launch of our Partner To Win 2020 programme to create a supplier ecosystem where partners work with us and each other to create breakthroughs in products or packaging to deliver the capacity, innovation and sustainable solutions to meet our growth ambition. A great example is the new Dove Body Wash bottle using 15% less plastic (see inside front cover).
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('our', 'us', 'we') that launched the Partner To Win 2020 programme and has growth ambitions.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The 'supplier ecosystem' and 'partners' that work with the company and each other, representing multiple organizations in a collaborative network.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] A company launched the Partner To Win 2020 programme that created a collaborative supplier ecosystem to deliver innovation and sustainable solutions like the new Dove Body Wash bottle using 15% less plastic.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company launching the Partner To Win 2020 programme is an organizational scale entity.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The supplier ecosystem and partners working together represent an inter-organizational scale.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] The company's Partner To Win 2020 programme fosters collaboration among suppliers to drive innovation and sustainability.
o4_mini: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
o4_mini: Causal Pathway: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal

o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] The launch of the Partner To Win 2020 programme fosters collaboration among suppliers to innovate sustainable packaging solutions.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] An organization's program to foster a collaborative supplier ecosystem aims to create product innovations leading to sustainable solutions for the environment.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever’s value chain – the process by which we create brands, products and ultimately shareholder value – begins with acquiring insight into consumers’ needs, which vary considerably between developed and emerging markets.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers and their needs are explicitly mentioned as driving Unilever's value chain.; Organizational: Unilever as a company creates brands, products, and shareholder value based on consumer insights.; Environmental and Societal: The text mentions different market contexts (developed and emerging markets) that represent broader societal structures.
claude3.7: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Consumer needs inform Unilever's organizational value creation process, which is then adapted to different market contexts (developed vs. emerging markets).
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers' needs represent the individual scale as they pertain to specific individuals or informal groups.; Organizational: Unilever as a company represents the organizational scale.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The value chain involves multiple organizations and sectors, such as suppliers and distributors.
4o: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Consumers' needs influence Unilever's organizational strategies, which then affect the broader value chain.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers' needs and preferences are identified at the individual level.; Organizational: Unilever, as an organization, utilizes these insights to shape its value chain.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The insights into consumer needs can also reflect broader market trends that influence multiple organizations.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Insights into consumer needs drive Unilever's brand and product strategies, impacting the broader market landscape.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Individual -> Organizational] Unilever's value chain begins by acquiring insight into consumer needs, which are significantly influenced by varying developed and emerging markets.

Full Paragraph Text: Insight requires close engagement with consumers, often over prolonged periods, and allows us to identify future trends to gain a competitive edge.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers who provide insights through close engagement; Organizational: The company/business that engages with consumers to gain competitive edge
claude3.7: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational] Consumer insights (Individual scale) directly inform organizational strategy and competitive positioning (Organizational scale).
4o: Summary: N/A

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] An organization's engagement with individual consumers provides insight that helps them identify future societal trends.

Full Paragraph Text: That knowledge helps us to target our subsequent R&D activities and our investments in innovation. Unilever has filed more than 200 new patent applications in 2014 and our Partner To Win 2020 programme, also launched in 2014, creates a new platform for us to work with our suppliers in the development of product and packaging innovations that capture consumers’ interest and attention.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company filing patents and directing R&D activities.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The 'Partner To Win 2020 programme' explicitly creates a platform for Unilever to work with multiple suppliers (other organizations) on innovations.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's creation of the Partner To Win 2020 programme establishes a new platform for collaborative innovation with multiple suppliers.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as a company, is engaging in R&D and innovation activities.; Inter-Organizational: The 'Partner To Win 2020 programme' involves collaboration with suppliers, indicating interactions between Unilever and other organizations.; Individual: The ultimate goal is to capture consumers' interest and attention, which involves individual consumers.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's R&D and innovation efforts, through collaboration with suppliers, aim to capture consumer interest.
o4_mini: Causal Pathway: Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a specific organization that is engaging in R&D and innovation activities.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The Partner To Win 2020 programme involves collaboration with suppliers, indicating interaction between multiple organizations.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's R&D and collaboration with suppliers drive innovations that aim to meet consumer needs and impact the market.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a specific company, representing an organizational entity.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The 'Partner To Win 2020 programme' explicitly involves 'working with our suppliers,' which refers to interactions within a supply chain, a group of organizations.; Individual:  'Consumers' refer to individual people whose interest and attention are being targeted by the innovations.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Individual] Unilever (Organizational) is leveraging a program to work with its suppliers (Inter-Organizational / Sector) to develop innovations that aim to capture consumers' (Individual) interest.

Full Paragraph Text: Bringing these innovations to market as physical products is a core function of Unilever’s supply chain, which employs about 110,000 of our 172,000 people. It also involves working with suppliers around the world.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company with its internal supply chain function and employees.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The explicit mention of 'working with suppliers around the world' indicates cross-organizational relationships in a supply chain context.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's organizational function of bringing innovations to market extends beyond its internal operations to causally engage with its global supplier network.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single organization with a defined supply chain and workforce.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The supply chain involves working with suppliers around the world, indicating interactions with multiple organizations.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's supply chain operations involve collaboration with global suppliers to bring innovations to market.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single organization that employs a large workforce and is responsible for bringing innovations to market.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The supply chain involves collaboration with various suppliers globally, indicating interactions between multiple organizations.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's supply chain operations drive collaboration with global suppliers to bring innovations to market.
gemini2.5: Causal Pathway: Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Individual; Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: Unilever's supply chain is described as a system that brings innovations to market and involves working with external suppliers, aligning with the definition of 'The supply chain' as a system at the Inter-Organizational scale.; Individual: The '110,000 of our 172,000 people' specifically refers to the individuals or a large group of employees working within the supply chain.; Organizational: The 'suppliers around the world' are distinct companies or entities, each representing an individual organization that interacts with Unilever's supply chain.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Individual; Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational] Unilever's supply chain, functioning as an inter-organizational system, is responsible for employing a significant number of individuals and collaborating with various organizational suppliers globally to bring products to market.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever itself manufactures the majority of its products and we maintain an international network of 240 manufacturing sites. In sourcing large amounts of raw materials we also have a direct impact on the environment. By sourcing sustainably, we can protect scarce resources, ensure security of supply for our business and reduce price volatility while protecting the environment and enhancing people’s lives, which is at the heart of our Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP). More detail can be found on page 11.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company with its manufacturing network and sourcing practices.; Environmental and Societal: The environment and people's lives that are impacted by Unilever's sourcing practices.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational <-> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's sourcing practices directly impact the environment and society, while environmental conditions affect Unilever's supply security and price stability.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as a company, is involved in manufacturing and sourcing raw materials.; Environmental and Societal: The sourcing of raw materials impacts the environment and societal resources.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's sourcing practices directly impact environmental resources and societal well-being.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as a single organization, influences its manufacturing processes and sourcing strategies.; Environmental and Societal: The sourcing of raw materials has a direct impact on environmental sustainability and societal well-being.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's sustainable sourcing practices directly impact environmental protection and societal well-being.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a specific company, and its manufacturing sites, sourcing practices, business operations, and the Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) all represent activities and entities at the organizational scale.; Environmental and Societal: The 'environment' and 'scarce resources' refer to natural systems, while 'people’s lives' and 'communities' represent societal-level systems, fitting the environmental and societal scale.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] Unilever's sourcing of raw materials impacts the environment, and by sourcing sustainably, the organization aims to protect scarce resources and enhance societal well-being, which in turn ensures security of supply and reduces price volatility for its business.

Full Paragraph Text: By the time manufacturing is under way Unilever’s marketing teams have worked with our category experts to define the complete marketing mix, including communications, that makes our brands come alive. Communicating the benefits of our products and brands to consumers is increasingly complex, with digital communications and social media creating new and more direct ways to engage alongside traditional media.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company, including its marketing teams and category experts who define the marketing mix and communications strategy.; Individual: Consumers who are the target of Unilever's communications and with whom the company engages through various media channels.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's marketing teams develop and implement communications strategies to engage with individual consumers through multiple channels including digital, social, and traditional media.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever's marketing teams and category experts are part of the organizational scale.; Individual: Consumers who engage with the brand through digital communications and social media represent the individual scale.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's marketing strategies directly influence consumer engagement through digital and traditional media.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever's marketing teams are part of the organization that defines the marketing mix.; Environmental and Societal: The communication strategies impact consumers and society at large, influenced by digital and social media.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's marketing strategies shape how consumers engage with their brands in a complex media landscape.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, its marketing teams, and category experts represent a single organization and its internal units, responsible for defining and executing marketing strategies.; Individual: Consumers are specific individuals or informal groups targeted by Unilever's communications.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's marketing teams define communications to directly engage and convey brand benefits to consumers.

Full Paragraph Text: Our logistics operations move Unilever products to retailers and our go-to-market teams ensure that we get enough of the right products in the right price bracket in the right sales channels for consumers to buy, be they stores or the fast-growing e-commerce channel.

4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single organization involved in logistics and go-to-market operations.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The logistics operations involve moving products to retailers, which are part of a supply chain.; Individual: Consumers are individuals who purchase products from sales channels.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Individual] Unilever's logistics and go-to-market strategies ensure product availability in sales channels, influencing consumer purchases.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The logistics operations and go-to-market teams are part of Unilever, which is a single organization.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The operations involve moving products to retailers, indicating interaction with other organizations in the supply chain.; Individual: Consumers are mentioned as the end-users of the products, representing individual preferences and behaviors.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Individual] Unilever's logistics and marketing strategies influence product availability for consumers across various sales channels.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, its logistics operations, go-to-market teams, and retailers/stores are all single organizations or internal units thereof.; Individual: Consumers are specific individuals or informal groups buying products.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's logistics and go-to-market operations, as organizational entities, facilitate the availability of products for individual consumers to buy.

Full Paragraph Text: We make the majority of what we sell through a network of more than 240 manufacturing sites around the world. We have invested significantly in our factories in recent years to create an efficient, reliable and more sustainable network. We are now able to maximise the global scale of our operations, while having the agility to meet local demands. More eco-efficient production is helping us meet the USLP targets, so by the end of January 2015, for instance, all our factories had achieved zero non-hazardous waste to landfill, producing 140,000 tonnes less waste. Since 2008, we estimate that eco-production has avoided costs in excess of €400 million.
claude3.7: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company making strategic decisions about its manufacturing approach and sustainability targets.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The 'network of more than 240 manufacturing sites around the world' represents an inter-organizational supply chain system.; Environmental and Societal: Environmental impacts are referenced through waste reduction (140,000 tonnes less waste) and zero non-hazardous waste to landfill targets.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's organizational decisions to invest in eco-efficient production across its manufacturing network directly resulted in environmental benefits including zero non-hazardous waste to landfill and 140,000 tonnes less waste.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company operates a network of over 240 manufacturing sites globally.; Environmental and Societal: The company's eco-efficient production contributes to environmental sustainability by reducing waste and avoiding costs.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] The company's investment in eco-efficient production at its factories leads to significant waste reduction and cost savings, contributing to environmental sustainability.
o4_mini: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational

'Eco-efficient production' and 'avoided costs' are also internal organizational aspects.; Environmental and Societal: The phrase 'producing 140,000 tonnes less waste' and 'achieved zero non-hazardous waste to landfill' directly describe an impact on natural systems and waste management, which are components of the Environmental and Societal scale.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] The company's investment in eco-efficient production and achieving zero non-hazardous waste to landfill directly resulted in 140,000 tonnes less waste, impacting the environment.

Full Paragraph Text: How we move products from factories to customers is the role of our logistics operation. We are now rolling out our global network of logistics centres that organise movement of goods centrally and more efficiently, delivering savings, reduced stocks, reduced carbon emissions and improved customer service. These operational hubs now allow us to centralise other services too, including monitoring orders from customers through to payment.
claude3.7: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company's logistics operation and its global network of logistics centres represent a single organization's internal operations.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The supply chain system that moves products from factories to customers involves multiple organizations.; Environmental and Societal: The reduction in carbon emissions affects the broader environment.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] A company's implementation of centralized logistics centres directly leads to reduced carbon emissions affecting the broader environment.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The logistics operation and global network of logistics centres are part of the company's organizational structure.; Environmental and Societal: The reduction in carbon emissions and improved customer service have broader societal and environmental impacts.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] The company's logistics operation reduces carbon emissions and enhances customer service, impacting societal and environmental scales.

o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The logistics operation is part of a single organization managing product movement.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The global network of logistics centres interacts with various suppliers and customers.; Environmental and Societal: The initiative aims to reduce carbon emissions, impacting societal environmental goals.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] The logistics operation's rollout enhances product movement efficiency, benefiting suppliers and reducing carbon emissions.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The 'We' refers to a company, which is a single organization. The 'logistics operation', 'global network of logistics centres', 'operational hubs', 'factories', and the 'centralisation of services' are all internal units or processes of this organization.; Environmental and Societal: The 'reduced carbon emissions' directly impacts the natural environment, which falls under societal-level systems.; Individual: The 'customers' and 'improved customer service' refer to specific individuals or informal groups interacting with the organization's services and placing 'orders'.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> [Environmental and Societal, Individual]] An organization's rollout of a global logistics network leads to reduced carbon emissions for the environment and improved service for individual customers.

Full Paragraph Text: We work closely with retailers to win in the market place and make sure that our brands are always available, properly displayed and in the right price bracket. Our go-to-market capability ensures that we become the supplier of choice for our customers and trade partners, through strong joint business planning and in-store execution via Perfect Store programmes, to help deliver sustainable sales growth. This is essential for us to be able to add premium brand extensions to our product ranges, land product innovations on the shelves, enter new geographies and markets, and build our distribution strength to reach new consumers.

Full Paragraph Text: We spend about €7 billion annually on marketing, making us one of the world’s biggest advertisers. This ensures that our brands and products are consumers’ first choice. We use multiple media to achieve cut-through in a highly competitive and busy world. Traditional media channels continue to play a big part but digital communications have revolutionised the way marketing engages with people, creating entirely new sales and marketing opportunities. We create our own entertainment content, including Unilever brand advertising, and this is distributed, for example, by mobile devices in emerging markets.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company spending €7 billion on marketing and creating advertising content.; Individual: Consumers who are influenced to make Unilever products their 'first choice' through the marketing efforts.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's €7 billion marketing investment and content creation directly influences consumer purchasing decisions, making their brands the 'first choice' for individuals.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as a company, is making strategic marketing decisions.; Individual: Consumers are influenced by the marketing strategies and content distributed by Unilever.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's extensive marketing strategies directly influence consumer preferences and choices.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company is investing heavily in marketing to promote its brands and products.; Environmental and Societal: The marketing strategies and content created by the organization influence consumer choices and behaviors in society.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] The company's substantial marketing investment influences consumer preferences and choices in the market.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational -> Individual] The broader societal shift of digital communications has revolutionized how an organization's marketing engages with and influences individual consumers.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever’s portfolio has four categories: Personal Care, Foods, Refreshment and Home Care. We have 13 brands with sales of more than €1 billion. Brands are our biggest asset but also present a risk if they do not maintain value and relevance to consumers. That’s why innovation and remaining competitive are crucial. We launched new brands in 2014, backed by marketing and customer insight, for example Regenerate, a dental care product. In addition to the Qinyuan and Talenti Gelato & Sorbetto acquisitions, we are also in the process of acquiring the Camay and Zest brands, to expand categories and boost growth. To sharpen our portfolio in 2014 we disposed of Slim. Fast, Ragu and Bertolli in North America, and other non-core Foods brands.
Scale Disagreement: Environmental and Societal, Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company making strategic decisions about its brand portfolio, including acquisitions, disposals, and new brand launches.; Individual: Consumers whose preferences and behaviors influence Unilever's brand strategy, as indicated by 'maintain value and relevance to consumers' and 'marketing and customer insight'.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever’s products sell in more than 190 countries and are used by 2 billion consumers every day. Our business is organised across three geographies: the Americas; Europe; and markets comprising Asia, Australasia, Africa, Middle East, Turkey, Russia, Ukraine and Belarus. We also analyse operations by developed and emerging markets. This wide spread exposes us to economic and political risks beyond our control. However, the diversity of our portfolio and geographic reach help mitigate our exposure to any specific risk.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational <-> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's global operations are exposed to economic and political risks from the environmental and societal scale, while the organization's diversity simultaneously helps mitigate these external pressures.

Full Paragraph Text: We cannot achieve our Vision to double our size unless we find new ways to operate that decouple growth from our environmental impact, while using growth as an enabler for positive social impact. Launched in 2010, the Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) is our blueprint for sustainable growth. It is helping to drive profitable growth for our brands, save costs and fuel innovation.

claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational <-> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's corporate strategy (USLP) aims to decouple business growth from environmental impact while leveraging that growth to create positive social outcomes, creating a bidirectional relationship where sustainable practices drive profitability and business success enables greater environmental and social influence.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's organizational growth strategy and sustainable living plan aim to decouple its operations from negative environmental impact and enable positive social impact.

Full Paragraph Text: We are making good progress with our first goal: to help more than a billion people improve their health and well-being by 2020, reaching 397 million by the end of 2014. The progress on our second goal is more mixed. We have achieved zero non-hazardous waste to landfill from our factories, and continue to make significant reductions in the greenhouse gas (GHG) and water impacts of our manufacturing. But the consumer element of our target to halve the water and GHG impacts of our products remains a challenge. On waste reduction, new technology such as the roll-out of compressed deodorant sprays and our new Dove Body Wash bottles has enabled reductions. On our third goal, we are also making good progress. We are now sourcing more than half our agricultural raw materials sustainably and have reached around 800,000 smallholder farmers with help and training. We have created 70,000 women micro-entrepreneurs distributing our products in India while making progress on our new commitments to enhance livelihoods across the value chain.
claude3.7: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
claude3.7: Causal Pathway: Organizational -> Individual, Organizational -> Environmental and Societal, Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector

claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual, Organizational -> Environmental and Societal, Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] A company's sustainability initiatives are directly impacting individual wellbeing (reaching 397 million people), environmental outcomes (zero waste to landfill, GHG reductions), and value chain improvements (reaching 800,000 smallholder farmers and creating 70,000 women micro-entrepreneurs).

Full Paragraph Text: Malnutrition – under and over nutrition – is an issue affecting the industry in both emerging and developed markets. This is creating a trend toward the manufacture of healthier food products, which either have fortified ingredients to improve dietary quality or address other dietary-related complaints such as unhealthy cholesterol levels.

Full Paragraph Text: Women play a pivotal role in the FMCG market, controlling the majority of purchasing decisions. The promotion of women’s rights and opportunities has clear long-term implications for the FMCG market in terms of product development and innovation. Significant developments such as the UN’s new Sustainable Development Goals are expected to accelerate these opportunities.

Full Paragraph Text: The trend is being driven in developed and also emerging markets where mobile phones are proving to be one of the most effective ways of delivering advertising to individuals, particularly in the most remote rural locations. For instance, large parts of rural India have no, or very limited, access to television, print or radio. However, mobile phone penetration and usage is high. As a result, Unilever has launched Kan Khajura Mobile Radio Station in India, which delivers radio content to mobile phones through the simple mechanism of giving a missed call.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a specific company launching the Kan Khajura Mobile Radio Station; Individual: Individual consumers in rural areas receiving advertising via mobile phones; Environmental and Societal: The broader context of developed and emerging markets, particularly rural India with limited media infrastructure
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's creation of the Kan Khajura Mobile Radio Station delivers advertising directly to individual consumers in remote rural locations through their mobile phones.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Individuals in rural India are the target audience receiving mobile radio content.; Organizational: Unilever, as an organization, is implementing the mobile radio station initiative.; Environmental and Societal: The societal context in rural India, with limited access to traditional media, influences the adoption of mobile-based solutions.
4o: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational -> Individual] Limited access to traditional media in rural India prompts Unilever to launch a mobile radio station, reaching individuals via mobile phones.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Individuals in rural areas are the end recipients of mobile advertising.; Organizational: Unilever is the organization implementing the mobile radio service.; Environmental and Societal: The broader societal context includes rural communities with limited access to traditional media.
o4_mini: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational -> Individual] The lack of traditional media access in rural areas drives Unilever to deliver advertising through mobile phones to individuals.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational -> Individual] Societal conditions in rural India, characterized by high mobile phone penetration and limited traditional media, led Unilever (Organizational) to launch a mobile radio service reaching individuals.

Full Paragraph Text: This mobile channel provides content including Bollywood movie songs, dialogues and jokes that can be interspersed with Unilever brand advertising. Data and analytics are extensively used to vary content to make it relevant and interesting. The channel reaches approximately 10 million people without a TV in Bihar and Jharkhand states, making it one of the largest media channels in these regions. The channel had 29.5 million users by the end of December 2014, helping increase spontaneous awareness of Unilever brands.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 many consumers have faced tough conditions as economic uncertainty has held back growth around the world, both in the developed markets and in emerging markets. Meanwhile consumption continues to be linked to many of the world’s biggest problems – deforestation, climate change, water scarcity, malnutrition and unhealthy diets.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: The text explicitly mentions 'consumers' who are facing tough economic conditions, representing individuals making consumption choices.; Environmental and Societal: The text identifies macro-level environmental and societal problems (deforestation, climate change, water scarcity, malnutrition) that are causally linked to consumption.

4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers are individuals who are facing tough economic conditions.; Environmental and Societal: The world's biggest problems like deforestation, climate change, and water scarcity are societal-level issues.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual <-> Environmental and Societal] Economic uncertainty impacts consumers, while their consumption patterns contribute to broader environmental and societal problems.

Full Paragraph Text: However, each of our categories continues to innovate to meet the challenges posed by these trends and changing consumer preferences, such as products that are sustainably sourced. Whether it’s laundry products which use less water or compressed cans for deodorant packaging with 25% less aluminium, consumers are reacting positively to our innovations.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Individual] -> Organizational -> Individual] Societal trends and individual consumer preferences drive organizational innovation, which in turn elicits positive reactions from individual consumers.

Full Paragraph Text: Acting alone Unilever can only do so much to make sustainable living commonplace. Acting in partnership with others it can help bring about transformational change at a societal level to tackle the world’s major social, environmental and economic issues. By adopting a leadership role, and working with governments, NGOs, suppliers and others, we are influencing change on a bigger scale, with a much bigger prize for the business on offer. We are deepening our efforts in three areas where we have scale, influence and resources to create transformational change: deforestation; sustainable agriculture and smallholder farmers; and water, sanitation and hygiene.
claude3.7: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
claude3.7: Causal Pathway: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal

claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever initiates partnerships with suppliers, NGOs and governments to create transformational change at the societal level in sustainability issues like deforestation, agriculture, and water/sanitation.

Full Paragraph Text: Delivering our business goals requires Unilever to recruit, develop and retain the right talent. We are determined to help all our people to be the best they can be, to help fulfil their potential and the potential of the business. Training and development are crucial at all levels and we strive to create a working environment that respects the human rights and interests of all our employees. Ensuring gender equality is a fundamental part of our approach while our Purpose of making sustainable living commonplace is a commitment that our people can engage with every day and make a reality through their work.

Full Paragraph Text: Many of our leading brands have enjoyed success. Dove, our biggest brand, delivered another year of strong performance, driven by double-digit growth in deodorants and consistent performance in skin cleansing, which is rooted in a successful repeatable model of compelling communication and targeted innovation in bar and body wash. In hair, Dove’s success was helped by the strong start of the Advanced Hair Care range launched in the US and Europe. The brand is also building a premium offering with, for example, its new Oxygen Moisture hair care range in Europe and the launch of Dove Advanced Care solid deodorant sticks in the US.

Full Paragraph Text: We also made progress against our Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) commitment to improve opportunities for women with the Dove Self-Esteem project, which has already reached over 15 million people. The brand partnered with the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts to launch the ‘Free Being Me’ Girl Guides badge awarded to girls taking part in education on common body myths. Also working to improve livelihoods, Lifebuoy soap continues to drive the largest handwashing behavioural change programme in the world, having reached 257 million people in more than 16 countries between 2010 and 2014.

Full Paragraph Text: Regenerate is the first dental care system to regenerate tooth enamel mineral, reversing the early enamel erosion process. The products work using our patented NR-5 technology and took scientists nine years of research across our R&D facilities in Port Sunlight, Milan and Shanghai to master. At each use, the NR-5 specific ingredients combine to form a fresh supply of enamel mineral which wraps and integrates on to teeth.

Full Paragraph Text: The category accounts for 25% of Group turnover and 45% of operating profit and its strategic role is to accelerate growth while maintaining above average cash and profit. Full Paragraph Text: North America is one of the largest geographies for ice cream where consumption is high, but the market is challenging with regional and local supermarket brands operating at low prices and low margins. Although profitable growth has been tough, our business has shown the best improvement in several years. We have premiumised the portfolio, aided by innovations such as Ben & Jerry’s Cores and Breyers Gelato. Towards the end of 2014 we announced the acquisition of Talenti Gelato & Sorbetto.

Full Paragraph Text: Europe witnessed poor summer weather but we managed to grow sales and market share in a flat market. The ‘25 Year’ celebration of Magnum drove growth while innovations included downsized packs to enter the snacks market, such as the €1 Cornetto, and a responsible approach to nutrition, with all children’s ice creams now 110 calories or less. Magnum also now has more than 70% of its cocoa sustainably sourced from Rainforest Alliance certified farmers.

Full Paragraph Text: The category has delivered strong top line performance consistently, with growth averaging 8.1% per annum over the last four years. Even in the tough operating conditions of 2014, it has had an underlying sales growth of 5.8%, well ahead of the market. The growth has been broad based, with our household care business continuing its strong performance, as we continued to expand our presence across markets. Laundry also grew strongly, with our biggest laundry brand Omo entering the Gulf markets in 2014.

Full Paragraph Text: Opportunities to upgrade consumers to newer benefits and more convenient formats not only drive growth, but also increase our operating margins by improving the mix of products we sell. Full Paragraph Text: Eco-packs use less plastic, meaning up to 70% less plastic used and a 50-85% reduction in greenhouse gases per consumer use. Simultaneously, a reduction in plastic packaging delivers a significant cost saving, allowing us to pass on lower costs to our consumers and improve the category profitability. Overall, eco-packs have a significantly lower impact on the environment compared to traditional packaging.

Full Paragraph Text: With this in mind, in 2014 Unilever examined where it can bring about improvements on a larger, societal scale by creating transformational change in key areas relevant to our business. These are: • the elimination of deforestation; • championing sustainable agriculture and the development of smallholder farmers; and • improving health and hygiene through handwashing, safe drinking water and sanitation.

Full Paragraph Text: Access to sustainable and plentiful raw materials reduces volatility and mitigates risk. More efficient use of energy and the development of packaging with less plastic further reduces costs. Brand reputation is defended and enhanced.

The actions ('Access to', 'More efficient use', 'development of packaging') are also undertaken by an organization.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever is one of the world’s biggest buyers of palm oil as a raw material for use in a number of our Foods and Personal Care brands. Palm oil is recognised as one of the four major commodities driving deforestation, which contributes up to 15% of the world’s greenhouse gas emissions.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is explicitly identified as a single company that buys palm oil for its brands.; Environmental and Societal: Deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions represent environmental impacts at a macro/global scale.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's large-scale palm oil purchasing contributes to deforestation, which in turn drives global greenhouse gas emissions.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as a company, is a major buyer of palm oil.; Environmental and Societal: Deforestation driven by palm oil production contributes significantly to global greenhouse gas emissions.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's palm oil purchasing contributes to deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as a major buyer of palm oil, influences sourcing practices and sustainability efforts.; Environmental and Societal: Deforestation driven by palm oil production impacts global greenhouse gas emissions and environmental health.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's palm oil sourcing practices contribute to deforestation, affecting global greenhouse gas emissions.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is identified as a single organization.; Environmental and Societal: Deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions are societal-level natural systems and environmental impacts.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's large-scale palm oil purchasing directly drives deforestation, which contributes significantly to greenhouse gas emissions.

Full Paragraph Text: We have committed to source 100% of our palm oil sustainably from certified, traceable sources by 2020. We also set ourselves the ambition that, by the end of 2014, all the palm oil we buy would be traceable to known sources. On that ambition we still have work to do but we have achieved a significant milestone in our European Foods business.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('we') making commitments about its own sourcing practices.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The palm oil supply chain that the company is trying to influence through its sustainable sourcing commitment.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] A company's commitment to source 100% sustainable palm oil by 2020 exerts influence on the broader palm oil supply chain by requiring certification and traceability.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The commitment and actions are made by a specific organization regarding its palm oil sourcing.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The sourcing of palm oil involves supply chains and certification bodies, which are part of the broader sector.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] The organization's commitment to sustainable palm oil sourcing influences the supply chain and certification processes.

o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] The company's commitment to sustainable palm oil sourcing influences supplier practices and impacts environmental systems.

Full Paragraph Text: In June 2014 Unilever, along with fellow members of the Consumer Goods Forum, called on heads of state for a binding global climate change deal. In September 2014 we helped facilitate the New York Declaration on Forests at the UN Climate Summit where more than 170 governments, companies and NGOs pledged to cut forest loss by half by 2020, end it by 2030 and restore 350 million hectares of degraded land.
claude3.7: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company taking action.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The Consumer Goods Forum, which is a coalition of multiple companies including Unilever.; Environmental and Societal: Heads of state/governments and the UN Climate Summit represent macro-level governmental structures.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever both individually and as part of the Consumer Goods Forum exerted influence on governmental bodies to create binding climate change commitments and forest protection agreements.
4o: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational

4o: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever and the Consumer Goods Forum influenced global climate policy through the New York Declaration on Forests.

Full Paragraph Text: Also in the same month, Unilever and the World Resources Institute announced a partnership aimed at increasing transparency in agricultural commodity supply chains. This will enable Unilever and our suppliers to use the Global Forest Watch Commodities platform to monitor forest cover change around commodity supply areas and processing facilities such as palm oil mills.

claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever and WRI's partnership enables monitoring of forest cover change across agricultural commodity supply chains, affecting transparency at the sector level.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single organization involved in the partnership.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The partnership involves the World Resources Institute and the broader agricultural commodity supply chains.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's partnership with the World Resources Institute aims to enhance transparency in agricultural commodity supply chains.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever’s work in moving from commitment to action in combating deforestation has been recognised. In November, we were ranked joint first for corporate action on tackling deforestation in our sector by CDP, formerly the Carbon Disclosure Project. The CDP report was produced on behalf of 240 investors, who together represent US $15 trillion in assets, and analysed the disclosures of 152 companies from around the world. It said: “Companies that regularly respond to CDP’s forests program are now identifying many more opportunities available to them, including securing their supply chain against the risks associated with deforestation and commodity sourcing. This in turn is helping to secure shareholder value.”
claude3.7: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company taking action on deforestation.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: CDP (formerly Carbon Disclosure Project) as an organization that coordinates across multiple companies and investors.; Environmental and Societal: The broader environmental issue of deforestation that affects ecosystems.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational <-> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's corporate actions combat deforestation (affecting environmental systems), while deforestation risks simultaneously influence Unilever's supply chain security and business operations.

4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's actions against deforestation influence sector-wide practices and contribute to environmental sustainability.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] Unilever's corporate action against deforestation is recognized by societal-level investors via the CDP report, which in turn helps secure shareholder value for companies, reinforcing the importance of such organizational actions.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we were able to announce a significant achievement that by the end of the year all palm oil directly sourced for Unilever’s European Foods business was close to 100% traceable and certified sustainable (over 98% in December 2014 and on track to be 100% by the end of March 2015).
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company making a direct sourcing decision and achievement announcement.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The palm oil supply chain that Unilever has made traceable and sustainable, involving multiple organizations across the supply chain.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's corporate decision to require sustainable palm oil has transformed its European supply chain to achieve nearly 100% traceability and sustainability certification.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever's European Foods business is a specific organization.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The sourcing and certification of palm oil involves multiple organizations within the supply chain.
4o: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational] The certification of palm oil by the supply chain directly influenced Unilever's ability to achieve traceability and sustainability goals.
o4_mini: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
o4_mini: Causal Pathway: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal

o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's commitment to sustainable palm oil sourcing influences the entire supply chain, promoting environmental sustainability.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational] Unilever’s achievement of nearly 100% traceable and certified sustainable palm oil indicates an organizational response to inter-organizational standards and supply chain demands, which are themselves driven by broader environmental and societal sustainability concerns.

Full Paragraph Text: On a global level Unilever is working hard to drive transparency in the palm oil supply chain. We now have visibility of about 1,800 crude palm oil mills, representing around two thirds of all mills in the global palm oil industry. We can also demonstrate traceability to a consumer product, which five years ago appeared unachievable. This represents a considerable breakthrough for Unilever and the food industry generally.
claude3.7: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company taking specific actions to drive transparency.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The palm oil supply chain involving multiple organizations and suppliers.; Environmental and Societal: The global palm oil industry as a macro-level system.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's efforts to drive transparency have created visibility across approximately two-thirds of all mills in the global palm oil supply chain, enabling traceability that benefits the entire food industry.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single organization working on transparency.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The palm oil supply chain involves multiple organizations and the food industry as a whole.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's efforts in transparency are influencing the broader palm oil supply chain and food industry.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational/Sector; Inter-Organizational/Sector -> Organizational; Inter-Organizational/Sector -> Inter-Organizational/Sector] Unilever's organizational efforts to increase transparency within the inter-organizational palm oil supply chain lead to breakthroughs for both Unilever itself and the broader inter-organizational food industry.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever is determined to work with the palm oil industry to drive deforestation out of its supply chain. Knowing the origin of palm oil is vital to halt deforestation.

Full Paragraph Text: We want to build on our progress in Europe by repeating the achievement internationally. One of the next steps is our new processing plant in Sei Mangke, Indonesia. The plant is a significant investment to source palm oil from known and certified sources for our global use.

claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] A company's investment in a new palm oil processing plant in Indonesia enables it to influence and engage with certified suppliers across the global palm oil supply chain.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company is making a significant investment in a new processing plant.; Environmental and Societal: The sourcing of palm oil from known and certified sources impacts global supply chains and environmental standards.

'Certified sources' also points to adherence to broader societal or market-level environmental standards.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 Unilever enhanced its Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) by introducing new pillars to its goal of enhancing livelihoods. These were: fairness in the workplace, where we will advance human rights across our operations and extended supply chain; opportunities for women, where we will empower 5 million women by 2020; and inclusive business, where we will have a positive impact on the lives of 5.5 million people by 2020.
Scale Disagreement: Environmental and Societal, Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company implementing its Sustainable Living Plan (USLP).; Individual: Workers in operations, women to be empowered, and people in the extended supply chain who will be impacted.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's enhanced sustainability plan aims to directly impact individuals through workplace fairness initiatives, women's empowerment programs, and inclusive business practices targeting 5.5 million people.

4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's USLP initiatives aim to enhance human rights and empower women, impacting both its supply chain and broader societal systems.

Full Paragraph Text: This latter commitment includes improving livelihoods of smallholder farmers and links directly to our USLP goal of reducing our environmental impact through sustainable sourcing.

Full Paragraph Text: Around half of Unilever’s raw materials come from farms or forests so sustainable agriculture is a strategic priority.
