Full Paragraph Text: Smallholder farmers produce 70% of the world’s food and make up 85% of the world’s farmers. Most grow their crops on less than two hectares and are often cut off from training so lack knowledge of how to maximise incomes by improving their agricultural practices. Many of our smallholder farmers are women.
claude3.7: Summary: N/A
4o: Summary: N/A
o4_mini: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Smallholder farmers are clearly defined as individuals or informal groups ('Most grow their crops on less than two hectares,' 'Many of our smallholder farmers are women') whose knowledge, practices, and incomes are directly impacted.; Environmental and Societal: 'The world’s food' represents a global food system, which is a societal-level system. The implied source of 'training' that farmers are 'cut off from' refers to societal-level infrastructure, support systems, or government programs designed to provide such knowledge.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual <-> Environmental and Societal] Smallholder farmers significantly contribute to the world's food supply, but their ability to maximize incomes and improve practices is hindered by a lack of access to training, suggesting a systemic failure from the Environmental and Societal level.

Full Paragraph Text: Through our own supply chain, our suppliers and our NGO partners, we are providing help and training to 800,000 smallholders to enable them to adopt sustainable practices. This helps them to increase yields, increase profits, invest and become more competitive while Unilever benefits from better yields, sustainably produced crops and security of raw material supply. However, assessing the impact of our programmes on farmers’ livelihoods is a complex area and our challenge is to find a practical and cost-effective means to demonstrate this.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company implementing programs and benefiting from better yields.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The supply chain and NGO partners working together to deliver training programs.; Individual: The 800,000 smallholder farmers who are receiving training and adopting sustainable practices.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational <-> Individual] Unilever provides training to smallholder farmers through its supply chain and NGO partners, helping farmers increase yields and profits, while Unilever benefits from better yields and security of sustainably produced raw materials.
4o: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: The involvement of supply chains and NGO partners indicates a sector-level interaction.; Individual: The smallholders (farmers) are individuals being directly impacted.; Organizational: Unilever is the organization benefiting from the program.

Full Paragraph Text: In February 2014 we signed a five-year partnership with the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) to improve the livelihoods of smallholder farmers. Signed by IFAD President Kanayo F Nwanze and our CEO, Paul Polman, the partnership aims to help improve food security, by raising agricultural productivity and linking farmers to markets.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company (with CEO Paul Polman) is a single organization making a partnership decision.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The partnership between the company and IFAD represents an inter-organizational collaboration aimed at affecting smallholder farmers.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] A company forms a partnership with IFAD, creating an inter-organizational initiative to improve smallholder farmer livelihoods and market access.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we published our Responsible Sourcing Policy (RSP). The RSP embodies our commitment to conduct business with integrity, openness, and respect for universal human rights and core labour principles. The RSP breaks new ground by defining a ‘continuous improvement ladder’ to help our suppliers move from a base level of ‘do no harm’ to ‘good practice’ and ultimately up to ‘best practice’ and as such is intended progressively to replace our Supplier Code in our dealings with key suppliers. The new code has been introduced to the supply base through communications and engagement from Procurement, and also through targeted events in critical markets such as Brazil, China and Vietnam.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company that published the Responsible Sourcing Policy (RSP) and whose Procurement department is implementing it.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The suppliers and supply base that are being influenced by the RSP, including specific mention of suppliers in Brazil, China and Vietnam.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] A company's implementation of its Responsible Sourcing Policy directly influences supplier behavior across its supply chain through a defined improvement ladder and targeted engagement.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The organization published the Responsible Sourcing Policy (RSP) and is actively engaging with its suppliers.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The policy is intended to influence the supply chain, which involves multiple organizations.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] The organization's Responsible Sourcing Policy aims to elevate supplier practices across the supply chain.
o4_mini: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
o4_mini: Causal Pathway: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal

o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] The company's Responsible Sourcing Policy drives improvements in supplier practices, ultimately enhancing societal standards for human rights and labor principles.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] An organization introduced a new Responsible Sourcing Policy to its supply base to guide suppliers towards continuous improvement.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever is one of the world’s biggest tea suppliers with brands such as Lipton, PG tips and Brooke Bond. We are helping to safeguard the world’s tea supply through an R&D programme to cultivate sustainable varieties.

Full Paragraph Text: Our partnership with Nature Source Genetics uses plant breeding to meet global demand while supporting communities that rely on the crop for income. The aim is to enhance productivity, quality and overall sustainability, and help stem any decline in crop diversity that could limit its ability to withstand drought, disease and pests.

claude3.7: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] An inter-organizational partnership between companies uses plant breeding to support income-dependent communities and address global crop demand while enhancing sustainability and crop diversity.

Full Paragraph Text: In his first Independence Day address in 2014, Narendra Modi, India’s new Prime Minister, made a commitment that by 2019 every Indian would have access to a toilet. The promise highlights that about 2.5 billion people globally are without access to adequate sanitation, good hygiene and safe drinking water. There are still 46 countries in the world where less than half the population has access to adequate sanitation facilities. 800,000 children die every year from diarrhoea caused by unsafe water, and poor sanitation and hygiene.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: The text refers to individual people (children dying, individuals without access to toilets) who are affected by sanitation issues.; Environmental and Societal: Government policy and national infrastructure initiatives (Modi's commitment as Prime Minister of India) represent societal-level structures and governance.
claude3.7: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Individual] The Indian government's national sanitation policy initiative aims to provide toilet access to individuals, addressing a problem that currently leads to individual-level health impacts including child mortality.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The commitment to provide every Indian with access to a toilet directly impacts individuals' daily lives and health.; Environmental and Societal: The global statistics on sanitation and hygiene reflect societal-level challenges and impacts, such as public health and mortality rates.
4o: Summary: [Individual -> Environmental and Societal] The Prime Minister's commitment to provide toilets aims to improve individual health and address broader societal sanitation challenges.
o4_mini: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Narendra Modi, as India's Prime Minister, represents a governmental entity, which is a societal-level system. The global and national statistics about sanitation issues (2.5 billion people without access, 46 countries, 800,000 children dying) also represent societal or environmental-level challenges.; Individual: 'Every Indian' and '800,000 children' refer to specific individuals or large groups of individuals whose access to facilities or health outcomes are directly impacted.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Individual] India's Prime Minister (Environmental and Societal) committed to a policy aimed at providing toilet access to every Indian (Individual).

Full Paragraph Text: Transformational change is needed to combat these issues. Unilever is uniquely placed to help because of our expertise in consumer behaviour change, our global reach and our portfolio of health and hygiene brands, including Domestos, Lifebuoy and Pureit, our water purifier. However, bringing about widespread, sustainable behaviour change is not something we can do alone, so we need to work closely with governments, NGOs, academia and funding partners to increase our reach and impact.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we committed to help 25 million people gain improved access to a toilet by 2020. By helping people who don’t have a toilet to get one and by promoting the benefits of using a clean toilet, we will open new markets and drive demand for our products.

Full Paragraph Text: Lifebuoy has long championed the health benefits of handwashing with soap and aims to change the hygiene behaviour of 1 billion consumers across Asia, Africa and Latin America. To achieve this ambition, we have to find ways to scale up our programmes: we need to develop lower cost, mass-scale behaviour change approaches and expand our partnerships and co-investment models. Lifebuoy has enjoyed four years of sequential double-digit sales growth.

claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Lifebuoy (a brand) is implementing behavior change programs to directly influence the handwashing habits of 1 billion individual consumers across multiple continents.

Full Paragraph Text: Women are the majority of our consumer base and their purchasing decisions are pivotal to our growth. They are strongly represented in our agricultural supply chains and in the distribution of our brands to market. At the same time we are a large employer and need the best available talent to succeed in our business goals.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as individual consumers making purchasing decisions; Organizational: The company as an employer seeking talent; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Agricultural supply chains and distribution networks where women are represented
claude3.7: Summary: [Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational] Women's individual purchasing decisions and their representation in supply chains/distribution networks directly impact the company's growth and business success.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as individual consumers and workers in the supply chain.; Organizational: The company as a large employer and brand distributor.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Agricultural supply chains and distribution networks.
4o: Summary: [Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector] -> Organizational] Women's roles as consumers and workers in supply chains influence the company's growth and talent acquisition.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as individual consumers influence purchasing decisions.; Organizational: The company relies on women as employees and consumers to achieve business goals.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Women are integral to agricultural supply chains and brand distribution.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational] Women's purchasing power and roles in supply chains significantly drive the company's growth and talent acquisition strategies.

gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual:  'Women' refers to specific individuals, acting as consumers making purchasing decisions and as talent/workers within supply chains.; Organizational:  'Our growth', 'we are a large employer', and 'our business goals' refer to a single company or organization.; Inter-Organizational / Sector:  'Agricultural supply chains' and 'distribution of our brands to market' describe groups of organizations working together, which are characteristics of the Inter-Organizational / Sector scale.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Mixed/Complex Pattern] Individual purchasing decisions drive organizational growth, individuals are strongly represented in inter-organizational supply chains, and the organization needs individual talent to achieve its business goals.

Full Paragraph Text: But women around the world face discrimination and disadvantage, lack access to skills and training, and face obstacles to economic participation.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as specific individuals facing personal obstacles to economic participation.; Environmental and Societal: Societal discrimination, lack of access to skills/training, and structural barriers that exist at a macro-level.
claude3.7: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Individual] Societal-level discrimination and structural barriers directly impact individual women's ability to access skills, training, and economic participation opportunities.
4o: Summary: N/A
o4_mini: Summary: N/A

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Individual] Societal discrimination and systemic obstacles hinder women's access to skills, training, and economic participation globally.

Full Paragraph Text: Our approach starts with respect for the rights of women, such as safety, and extends to their promotion as well as helping to develop skills and open opportunities, both in our own operations, where 43% of managers are women, and in our value chain.
Scale Disagreement: Environmental and Societal, Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('our own operations') is implementing policies and practices to promote women's rights and development.; Individual: Women as specific people are being affected by the organization's policies through promotion, skill development, and opportunities.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] The company's policies and practices directly impact individual women by promoting their rights, developing their skills, and creating opportunities both within the organization and throughout its value chain.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The focus on women's rights, safety, and skill development pertains to individual women.; Organizational: The company's operations and management structure, where 43% of managers are women, represent the organizational scale.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The mention of the value chain indicates interactions beyond a single organization, involving multiple organizations.
4o: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] Efforts to respect and promote women's rights and skills at the individual level influence organizational practices and extend into the broader value chain.

o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The organization promotes women's rights and skills development within its own operations.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The organization extends its efforts to influence the value chain, impacting other organizations.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] The organization's commitment to women's rights and skills development influences broader societal opportunities for women.

Full Paragraph Text: To this end we are implementing the UN Women’s Empowerment Principles across our business. These principles reinforce the direct action we also taking as a business.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: The UN Women's Empowerment Principles represent an inter-organizational framework or standard that multiple organizations can adopt.; Organizational: The text refers to 'our business' and 'we as a business' taking direct action and implementing the principles across their operations.
claude3.7: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational] The UN Women's Empowerment Principles (an inter-organizational framework) are being implemented within and influencing the actions of a single business organization.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The business itself is implementing the principles.; Environmental and Societal: The UN Women's Empowerment Principles are societal-level guidelines aimed at promoting gender equality.
4o: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] The implementation of UN Women's Empowerment Principles by the business reflects societal guidelines influencing organizational actions.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The business is implementing the UN Women’s Empowerment Principles as part of its internal policies.; Environmental and Societal: The UN Women’s Empowerment Principles aim to influence broader societal norms and practices regarding gender equality.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] The business's implementation of the UN Women’s Empowerment Principles aims to promote gender equality in society.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] A business implements UN Women’s Empowerment Principles, which reinforces the direct actions it is already taking.

Full Paragraph Text: For instance in Sekondi, Ghana, a three-day workshop by the Unilever Ghana Foundation taught 60 women how to think and act like entrepreneurs, coached them in bookkeeping procedures, and cash and working capital management. This brings to more than 700 the number of women trained in Ghana and supports Unilever’s commitment to empower 5 million women by 2020.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The Unilever Ghana Foundation is a formal organization conducting the workshop as part of Unilever's broader commitment.; Individual: The 60 women (and more broadly 700 women) who received entrepreneurship training represent individuals benefiting from the program.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] The Unilever Ghana Foundation's entrepreneurship workshop directly empowered 60 women (and more broadly 700 women) with business skills as part of the company's commitment to empower 5 million women.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The workshop targeted specific women, teaching them entrepreneurial skills.; Organizational: Unilever Ghana Foundation organized and conducted the workshop as part of its broader initiative.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] The Unilever Ghana Foundation's workshop empowered women by teaching them entrepreneurial skills.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: The 60 women participating in the workshop represent individual entrepreneurs being trained.; Organizational: The Unilever Ghana Foundation is an organization facilitating the training.; Environmental and Societal: The initiative contributes to broader societal goals of women's empowerment in Ghana.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] A workshop by the Unilever Ghana Foundation empowers women entrepreneurs, contributing to societal goals of women's empowerment.
gemini2.5: Causal Pathway: Organizational -> Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever Ghana Foundation is a part of a single organization, and 'Unilever’s commitment' refers to a strategic goal set by the organization.; Individual:  '60 women' are specific individuals who received training, representing the individual scale.; Environmental and Societal: The goal to 'empower 5 million women by 2020' signifies a large-scale societal impact aimed at addressing broader issues like economic development and gender equality.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] The Unilever Ghana Foundation trained individual women, an action that supports Unilever's broader organizational commitment, which ultimately aims to empower women at an environmental and societal level.

Full Paragraph Text: To date we have trained and recruited more than 3,400 women from nearly 1,100 villages in Pakistan as part of the Guddi Baji (‘Good Sister’) programme. This initiative helps increase sales as well as generating sustainable incomes for women through the sale of Unilever hygiene and personal care brands and through the provision of beauty services to other local women.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company implementing the Guddi Baji programme; Individual: The 3,400 women who are trained and recruited as Guddi Bajis, selling products and providing services; Environmental and Societal: The nearly 1,100 villages in Pakistan where the programme operates, representing communities at a societal level
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational <-> Individual] Unilever's Guddi Baji programme provides training and income opportunities for individual women in Pakistan, while these women in turn help increase sales for Unilever's hygiene and personal care brands.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The women from villages who are trained and recruited.; Organizational: Unilever, which runs the Guddi Baji programme and benefits from increased sales.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's Guddi Baji programme empowers women by providing training and income opportunities, thereby increasing sales.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women from local villages are trained and recruited as part of the program.; Organizational: Unilever, as a company, is involved in the initiative to promote its hygiene and personal care brands.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The program operates within a broader context of local communities and markets, influencing and being influenced by various organizations.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] The training of women in villages enhances Unilever's sales and contributes to local economic development.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to the '3,400 women' recruited and trained, and 'other local women' who receive beauty services, highlighting their personal economic activity and income generation.; Organizational: Relates to 'Unilever' as a company, the 'Guddi Baji programme' as an initiative of Unilever, and the goal to 'increase sales' for Unilever brands.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Organizational] Unilever's Guddi Baji programme (Organizational) empowers women (Individual) to generate income through sales and services, which in turn increases sales for Unilever (Organizational).

Full Paragraph Text: In India, recruiting and training more women entrepreneurs (Shakti Ammas) were central to our rural expansion in 2014, reaching more remote villages.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company (implied by 'our rural expansion') is implementing a strategy to expand its reach.; Individual: Women entrepreneurs (Shakti Ammas) who are being recruited and trained as individuals.; Environmental and Societal: Remote rural villages in India represent a societal/community scale.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] A company's strategy to recruit and train women entrepreneurs (Shakti Ammas) enabled its expansion into remote rural villages in India.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The women entrepreneurs (Shakti Ammas) represent specific individuals being recruited and trained.; Organizational: The recruitment and training initiative is part of a rural expansion strategy by an organization.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] An organization's rural expansion strategy involves recruiting and training women entrepreneurs to reach remote villages.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women entrepreneurs (Shakti Ammas) are specific individuals being recruited and trained.; Organizational: The organization is expanding its operations and initiatives to support these entrepreneurs.; Environmental and Societal: The initiative aims to impact rural communities and societal structures in remote villages.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] An organization's strategy of recruiting and training individual women entrepreneurs enables its rural expansion, which subsequently reaches remote villages.

Full Paragraph Text: Our programmes also help young women and men. Our Wall’s team has developed a youth employment programme, known as ‘Feet on the Street’, to help tackle the youth jobless rate in Europe while driving our growth agenda by bringing ice cream to the streets. Wall’s provides tools and equipment, such as trikes or push carts and freezers, to enable a micro-entrepreneur to run his or her own mini-business selling ice cream and also to provide young people with their first job experience. In Portugal, Spain and Italy, 250 seasonal jobs were also created to enhance livelihoods while boosting ice cream sales. Our ambition is to have 50,000 micro-entrepreneurs by 2020 with a potential contribution to turnover of more than €100 million.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Wall's (a company/brand) has developed and is implementing the 'Feet on the Street' youth employment programme.; Individual: Young women and men, specifically micro-entrepreneurs and seasonal workers who receive employment opportunities and resources to run their own mini-businesses.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Wall's company provides tools, equipment, and opportunities that directly enable individual micro-entrepreneurs to establish their own ice cream selling businesses while addressing youth unemployment.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Young individuals are provided with job opportunities and tools to become micro-entrepreneurs.; Organizational: Wall’s team develops and implements the youth employment programme.; Environmental and Societal: The programme aims to tackle the youth jobless rate in Europe, impacting societal-level employment statistics.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] Wall’s youth employment programme empowers young individuals as micro-entrepreneurs, contributing to reducing youth unemployment in Europe.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Young men and women are directly involved as micro-entrepreneurs and seasonal workers.; Organizational: Wall's is the organization implementing the youth employment programme.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The programme addresses the broader issue of youth unemployment in Europe, indicating a sector-wide impact.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] Wall's youth employment programme creates jobs for young people while addressing youth unemployment in Europe.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Organizational & Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Wall's develops a youth employment program empowering individuals to become micro-entrepreneurs, which directly drives the company's growth and sales, while concurrently addressing the societal youth jobless rate and enhancing livelihoods.

Full Paragraph Text: Domestos has led our efforts on sanitation in partnership with UNICEF. Our brand, together with the Unilever Foundation, supports UNICEF’s Community Approaches to Total Sanitation (CATS) programme which aims to eliminate open defecation by changing people’s behaviour and promoting demand for sanitation. Domestos contributed 5% of its average proceeds from specially marked bottles on sale in certain markets to UNICEF. Domestos sales continue to grow strongly and were up 7.3% in 2014.
Scale Disagreement: Environmental and Societal, Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Domestos is a brand (part of Unilever) that is taking specific actions including contributing 5% of proceeds from marked bottles.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The partnership between Domestos/Unilever Foundation and UNICEF represents collaboration between multiple organizations.; Individual: The program explicitly targets changing individual people's behavior regarding sanitation practices.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Individual] Domestos (brand) provides funding to an inter-organizational partnership with UNICEF, which then implements programs to change individual sanitation behaviors.
4o: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
4o: Causal Pathway: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Domestos, as a brand under Unilever, is an organization contributing to sanitation efforts.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The partnership between Domestos, the Unilever Foundation, and UNICEF represents collaboration across multiple organizations.; Environmental and Societal: The CATS programme aims to eliminate open defecation, impacting societal-level sanitation systems.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] Domestos' partnership with UNICEF through the CATS programme aims to improve societal sanitation by eliminating open defecation.
o4_mini: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational

o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] Domestos's partnership with UNICEF drives initiatives to improve sanitation and eliminate open defecation.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Domestos, Unilever Foundation, and UNICEF are all specific organizations or entities within an organization, leading and supporting the sanitation efforts and programs.; Individual: 'People's behaviour' directly refers to the actions and choices of individuals or informal groups, which the program aims to change.; Environmental and Societal: 'Eliminate open defecation' and 'promoting demand for sanitation' represent large-scale societal outcomes and changes in public health and environmental systems.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] Organizational entities (Domestos, Unilever, UNICEF) collaborate on a program that aims to change individual behavior, which in turn leads to the elimination of a societal-level issue (open defecation) and promotes public sanitation.

Full Paragraph Text: We believe we can create a brighter future for our children. Project Sunlight is a growing community of people who believe it is possible to build a world where everyone lives well and lives sustainably. The campaign continues to engage people in programmes that can help to contribute to a #brightfuture – almost 180 million ‘acts of sunlight’ were pledged by the end of December 2014.
claude3.7: Summary: N/A
4o: Summary: N/A
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Individuals are engaging in 'acts of sunlight' to contribute to sustainability.; Organizational: Project Sunlight represents an organized campaign aimed at fostering community engagement.; Environmental and Societal: The initiative aims to create a sustainable future for society as a whole.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Individuals participating in Project Sunlight contribute to a collective effort for a sustainable future.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Project Sunlight is presented as a 'campaign' and a 'community' that 'continues to engage people in programmes', indicating a formal, structured initiative launched by an organization.; Individual: Refers to the 'community of people' and the 'people' who 'pledged' acts of sunlight, representing specific individuals or informal groups participating in the campaign.; Environmental and Societal: The aims of creating a 'brighter future' and a 'world where everyone lives well and lives sustainably' refer to broad societal and natural systems outcomes.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] An organizational campaign, Project Sunlight, engages individuals to perform 'acts of sunlight' that contribute to a sustainable future for society and the environment.

Full Paragraph Text: A team in Nigeria looked at how to bring the concept of a Perfect Village to life in Africa, embracing broad areas such as water, health, hygiene, nutrition, women’s empowerment and smallholder farming. They developed a strategy we can take forward globally. Their work took them from the classroom to the field as they brought their pilot programme to life.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: A team in Nigeria that developed a strategy represents an organizational entity working as a formal group.; Environmental and Societal: The 'Perfect Village' concept and its implementation affects communities and societal structures in African villages, including areas like water, health, and women's empowerment.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] A Nigerian team developed and implemented a 'Perfect Village' strategy that directly impacts community-level outcomes across multiple dimensions including water, health, and women's empowerment.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The team members who developed and implemented the strategy.; Organizational: The team as a formal group working on the Perfect Village concept.; Environmental and Societal: The broader societal impact areas such as water, health, and women's empowerment.
4o: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] A team in Nigeria developed a strategy for the Perfect Village concept, impacting societal areas like health and women's empowerment.
o4_mini: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Individuals in the team engaged in practical applications of their strategy.; Organizational: The team represents an organization that is implementing the Perfect Village concept.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The strategy developed can be applied across various organizations and sectors globally.; Environmental and Societal: The initiative addresses broader societal issues such as health, nutrition, and women's empowerment.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] A team in Nigeria develops a strategy for the Perfect Village concept that addresses health and empowerment issues on a global scale.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational <-> Environmental and Societal] An organizational team embraces societal issues to develop a global strategy, implementing a pilot program in real-world environmental and societal contexts.

Full Paragraph Text: Access to training and skills for women and to advancing women’s rights. A key aspect of this has been our safety programme for women and girls, with the involvement of men and boys, which we have begun at our tea plantation in Kericho, Kenya, in response to reports of sexual harassment in 2013. The programme is being rolled out to other locations. More information on our progress on women’s rights is in the Society section on pages 22 to 24, with full details to be published in our Sustainable Living Report 2014 which will be found on www.unilever.com/sustainable-living in May 2015.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company implementing a safety programme at their tea plantation in Kericho, Kenya.; Individual: Women and girls (and men and boys) who are affected by and participate in the safety programme addressing sexual harassment.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Unilever implemented a safety programme at their tea plantation in Kenya to address sexual harassment issues, directly affecting the safety and rights of individual women and girls.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The programme involves individual men and boys, as well as women and girls, at the tea plantation.; Organizational: Unilever, as an organization, is implementing the safety programme.; Environmental and Societal: The programme aims to advance women's rights, which is a societal-level issue.
4o: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] The involvement of individuals in Unilever's safety programme at the tea plantation aims to advance women's rights at a societal level.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women and girls at the tea plantation are directly affected by the safety programme.; Organizational: Unilever is implementing the safety programme as part of its corporate responsibility initiatives.; Environmental and Societal: The programme aims to advance women's rights and address societal issues like sexual harassment.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] The safety programme for women and girls at the tea plantation aims to enhance women's rights and safety, reflecting Unilever's commitment to societal change.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> [Individual, Environmental and Societal]] Reports of individual sexual harassment triggered an organizational safety program, which in turn benefits individuals directly and contributes to advancing women's rights at the societal level.

Full Paragraph Text: To achieve Unilever’s Vision of doubling the size of its business, reducing its environmental footprint and increasing its positive social impact, we need to ensure the talent in the business today can realise these ambitions in future.
claude3.7: Summary: N/A

Full Paragraph Text: Some years ago we set three priorities for the development of our employees around the world. They were to: • build depth of capability and leadership; • live our values and build a performance culture; and • build an agile, flexible and diverse organisation.

4o: Summary: N/A

Full Paragraph Text: These priorities still underpin everything we do. Our people are also the embodiment of the Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) – without their commitment and belief, the business could not achieve the plan’s three main goals of improving health and well-being, reducing our environmental impact and enhancing livelihoods. More than 75% of employees say they can contribute to the USLP in their roles and help realise our Vision.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: Unilever employees ('Our people') who embody the plan and contribute through their commitment and belief; Organizational: Unilever as a company with its Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) and organizational goals
claude3.7: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational] Individual employee commitment and belief enables Unilever (organization) to achieve its Sustainable Living Plan goals, with over 75% of employees contributing to the plan through their roles.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The employees of Unilever are mentioned as key contributors.; Organizational: Unilever as a company is implementing the Sustainable Living Plan.

Full Paragraph Text: This independent measure reveals our success at engaging with future leaders which has been driven in part by our Future Leaders League. This is a global competition in which universities around the world send a representative team of undergraduates to our Four Acres campus in Singapore. They are each set a demanding case study to run one of our brands, which in 2014 was TRESemmé, with a strong sustainability theme.

4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Undergraduate students representing their universities.; Organizational: The organization hosting the Future Leaders League and managing the TRESemmé brand.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Universities from around the world participating in the competition.
4o: Summary: [Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational] Undergraduate teams from global universities influence the host organization through their participation in the Future Leaders League competition.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Undergraduate students participating in the competition represent individual future leaders.; Organizational: The organization hosting the Future Leaders League and the brand TRESemmé are part of the same entity.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Universities from around the world are involved, creating a network of organizations participating in the competition.

Full Paragraph Text: Every year, our people nominate ‘Unilever heroes’ for work that brings our Purpose to life. Anila Gopal, Global Social Mission Manager for Lifebuoy, based in India, is a Unilever hero. She is helping to run the world’s largest handwashing behaviour change programme that demonstrates how using soap could help save children from deadly, but preventable, diseases.

4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The focus is on employee hours and their involvement in Performance & Development Planning assessments.; Organizational: The organization implemented changes to internal processes to achieve time savings.

Full Paragraph Text: Elsewhere, over 2013-14, there has been a 51% reduction in the number of internal reports prepared for leadership teams, releasing time to focus on more productive activity. We also simplified the GPS which we ask all employees to complete annually, enabling us to cut the time individuals spent completing the survey significantly.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2013 we successfully ran the Winning Together Campaign to drive more inclusive and efficient ways of working among teams in the organisation. Building on that, in 2014 we launched a second campaign called Time Saving Idea to make simplification a habit and encouraged employees to try simple time-saving ideas. As a result more than 10,000 ideas were tried and rated by our employees.

Full Paragraph Text: In the supply chain we have taken a broad approach to building capabilities for our employees. This includes a host of skills development programmes for blue and white collar employees. Training in core skills is mandatory across 130 roles. Skill assessments are completed every two years and the data is used to understand and address specific gaps across roles, capabilities and geographies.

Full Paragraph Text: Our aim is to improve the safety and well-being not only of our employees, but also of the wider community in which Unilever operates, with our Vision Zero strategy – zero fatalities, zero injuries, zero motor vehicle accidents, zero process incidents, zero tolerance of unsafe behaviour and practices – serving as our foundation. To meet our commitments, we assess and reduce risk through a variety of programmes, including our continued work to address behaviour safety, process safety, safe travel and construction safety.

4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single organization implementing the Vision Zero strategy.; Environmental and Societal: The strategy aims to improve the safety and well-being of the wider community.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014, we introduced a step change in our Safe Travel programme. With more people on the road than ever before, including many in developing countries where there is a higher risk of car accidents, we released a revised and strengthened travel standard that includes programmes and strategies specifically targeted at high and medium risk locations. By the middle of 2015, we will also have in place a mandatory global ban on using all hand-held and hands-free mobile phone devices while driving on company business.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('we') implementing a revised travel standard and mandatory ban on mobile phone use while driving.; Individual: The employees/people who travel for the company and who will be subject to the mobile phone ban while driving.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] A company's implementation of a strengthened travel standard and mandatory ban on mobile phone use directly regulates and constrains the behavior of individual employees while driving on company business.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company introduced a revised travel standard and a global ban on mobile phone use while driving on company business.; Environmental and Societal: The programme targets high and medium risk locations, including developing countries, impacting societal-level road safety.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] The company's revised travel standards and mobile phone ban aim to improve road safety in high-risk locations, including developing countries.

Full Paragraph Text: This year saw considerable advancement in our behavioural-based approach to health and safety, with 84% of our manufacturing and 38% of our non-manufacturing sites now having rolled out the first phase of the BeSafE programme. This includes training 79 master coaches and 91 trainers, who have in turn trained more than 1,840 employees.

claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] A company's implementation of the BeSafE health and safety programme cascades down to affect individual employees through structured training.

Full Paragraph Text: 2014 also saw some challenges. Our overall safety performance, as measured by the Total Recordable Frequency Rate (TRFR), increased slightly from 1.03 to 1.05 per 1 million hours worked due to a spike in injury rates in the first quarter of the year. With a renewed focus on safety programmes and initiatives, in co-operation with our project partners, injury rates have been brought back down since the first quarter.

claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational <-> Inter-Organizational / Sector] A company collaborated with its project partners to implement safety programs that successfully reduced injury rates after an initial spike.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The safety performance and injury rates are specific to the organization in question.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The cooperation with project partners indicates involvement of multiple organizations.
4o: Summary: [Organizational <-> Inter-Organizational / Sector] The organization's safety performance was influenced by cooperation with project partners, leading to improved injury rates.

o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The organization is implementing safety programmes and initiatives.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The organization is cooperating with project partners to improve safety performance.

Full Paragraph Text: Women are Unilever’s core consumers, controlling nearly two thirds of consumer spending, so it’s important that we represent them in our workforce. In fact, 2014 marks five years since we began the process of building an agile and diverse Unilever and making sure we have the right gender balance throughout the organisation.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as consumers who control consumer spending represent the individual scale.; Organizational: Unilever as a company implementing organizational changes to achieve gender balance represents the organizational scale.
claude3.7: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational] Women's significant consumer spending power (controlling nearly two-thirds of consumer spending) has influenced Unilever to implement organizational changes focused on gender balance and workforce diversity.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as individual consumers who control consumer spending.; Organizational: Unilever as a company aiming to represent women in its workforce.
4o: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational] Women's consumer spending power influences Unilever's efforts to ensure gender balance in its workforce.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Women as individual consumers influence Unilever's business strategies.; Organizational: Unilever is actively working to build a diverse workforce that reflects its core consumer base.; Environmental and Societal: The representation of women in the workforce aligns with broader societal goals of gender balance and diversity.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Women consumers drive Unilever to enhance gender diversity in its workforce, reflecting societal values.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'women' as individual consumers who collectively exert significant purchasing power.; Organizational: Refers to 'Unilever' as a single company, its workforce, and internal organizational policies regarding gender balance.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational] The collective purchasing power of women as core consumers directly influences Unilever's organizational strategy to ensure gender representation and balance within its workforce.

Full Paragraph Text: By the end of 2014, over 43% of our managers were women, up from 38% in 2010. The hard work we are doing to retain more women in our workforce by promoting flexible working, women’s networks, job shares and maternity and paternity support is paying benefit and will remain a focus area.

claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] The company's implementation of supportive policies (flexible working, women's networks, job shares, maternity/paternity support) has directly increased female manager retention, raising representation from 38% to 43%.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The organization is implementing policies and initiatives to retain women in the workforce.; Individual: Individual managers, specifically women, are being retained and promoted within the organization.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Organizational policies to support women have led to an increase in female managers.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The organization is implementing policies to support women in the workforce.; Individual: Individual women are benefiting from these organizational policies, leading to increased representation.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] The organization's policies to support women are leading to increased representation of women managers.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: References to 'women', 'managers', and 'workforce' indicate specific individuals or groups of employees within the organization.; Organizational: The phrases 'our managers', 'we are doing', 'our workforce', and specific initiatives like 'flexible working, women’s networks, job shares and maternity and paternity support' refer to the actions and characteristics of a single company or organization.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Organizational] An organization's initiatives to support and retain women in its workforce benefit the individual employees, which in turn leads to an increased percentage of women managers within the organization and reinforces the organizational focus on these efforts.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we paid particular attention to mental health initiatives. The rising incidence of mental ill health in the UK is reflected in our absence data. Help and support on nutrition, sleep, exercise and mindfulness all improve the day-to-day well-being of employees. A robust framework with support tools is now in place and is being rolled out across the organisation.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: Employees experiencing mental health issues, and individuals receiving support for nutrition, sleep, exercise, and mindfulness.; Organizational: The company implementing mental health initiatives and rolling out a support framework across the organization.
claude3.7: Summary: [Individual <-> Organizational] Employee mental health issues are reflected in organizational absence data, prompting the company to implement support initiatives that in turn improve individual employee well-being.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: The focus is on the well-being of employees, which pertains to individuals.; Organizational: The organization is implementing a framework and support tools for mental health initiatives.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] The organization's mental health initiatives aim to improve the well-being of employees.

o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] The organization's mental health initiatives enhance the well-being of employees.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Individual -> Organizational -> Individual] The rising incidence of mental ill health in the UK impacts individual employee well-being, which is reflected in the organization's absence data, prompting the organization to implement support frameworks that improve individual employee well-being.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we strengthened the enhancing livelihoods ambition of the USLP. An integral part of this is our implementation of the UN Guiding Principle on Business and Human Rights and our public reporting on this. We also committed to enhancing access to training and skills for women and to advancing women’s rights. A key aspect of this has been our safety programme for women and girls, with the involvement of men and boys, which we have begun at our tea plantation in Kericho, Kenya, in response to reports of sexual harassment in 2013. The programme is being rolled out to other locations. More information on our progress on women’s rights is in the Society section on pages 22 to 24, with full details to be published in our Sustainable Living Report 2014 which will be found on www.unilever.com/sustainable-living in May 2015.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company implementing specific programs and commitments, including their safety program at their tea plantation in Kericho, Kenya.; Environmental and Societal: UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights represent societal-level frameworks that guide organizational behavior. Women's rights advancement is also a societal-level concern.
claude3.7: Summary: [Environmental and Societal <-> Organizational] Unilever implements UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights in its operations while also developing programs to advance women's rights at the societal level through its organizational initiatives.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is implementing programs and policies at its tea plantation.; Environmental and Societal: The program addresses societal issues such as women's rights and safety, influenced by UN guidelines.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's safety program at its tea plantation in Kenya addresses societal issues of women's rights and safety.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The actions and commitments of Unilever as a company to enhance women's rights and safety.; Environmental and Societal: The broader societal impact of these initiatives, particularly in relation to women's rights and safety in communities.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's safety programme for women and girls at its tea plantation aims to improve women's rights and safety in the community.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'women and girls', 'men and boys', and 'reports of sexual harassment' which originate from specific people.; Organizational: Refers to 'we' (Unilever), 'our tea plantation', and 'safety programme', which are specific company entities or internal initiatives.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to the 'UN Guiding Principle on Business and Human Rights', representing a global, societal-level framework or standard.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Individual] -> Organizational -> Individual] Unilever's organizational safety program, a response to individual reports of sexual harassment and an implementation of UN Guiding Principles, aims to enhance the safety and rights of individuals.

Full Paragraph Text: This Strategic Report lays out how Unilever’s business works, the highlights of 2014 and the underlying importance of the Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP), to ensure that our business will remain relevant to future generations of consumers and investors. The following pages reveal how this adds up to sustainable value for shareholders.

Full Paragraph Text: At Unilever we look to the future and what the consumer of tomorrow will need. This has inevitably drawn us to increase our business in emerging markets where population and consumption growth offer attractive opportunities. In 2014, 57% of our turnover was generated in emerging markets.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company making strategic business decisions about where to operate.; Environmental and Societal: Emerging markets represent macro-level societal structures with population and consumption growth patterns.
claude3.7: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] Societal-level population and consumption growth in emerging markets directly influences Unilever's business strategy, leading to 57% of their turnover being generated in these markets.

Full Paragraph Text: These markets also bring challenges. Performance can prove volatile as witnessed in 2014. Economies have slowed and exchange rates have weakened leading to a reduction in consumer spending.

Full Paragraph Text: These markets are also among the most sensitive to environmental and social pressures brought about by growth in population and consumption and the activities of companies such as Unilever. That’s why our USLP goals are to improve health and well-being, reduce our environmental impact and enhance livelihoods through direct action and partnerships.

Full Paragraph Text: Our long-term track record of delivery for shareholders continued during 2014 despite some significant challenges in the business environment. These included continued weak consumer demand in developed markets, slowing demand in emerging markets and currency devaluations in many countries. The resilience of our business and the broad nature of our brand portfolio and geographic reach enabled us to deliver a year of steady progress in slower markets.

gemini2.5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal -> Organizational] Weak consumer demand and currency devaluations at the societal level presented significant challenges to the organization, which then leveraged its resilience and portfolio to deliver progress despite these external pressures.

Full Paragraph Text: In a lower growth environment we stepped up our cost savings initiatives. We accelerated Project Half for Growth which is simplifying the business and reducing costs, particularly in overheads. As a result we were able to continue to invest in sustained brand and marketing investment and deliver underlying sales growth ahead of our markets and a further improvement in core operating margin.

Full Paragraph Text: In June 2014 we sold the Ragu and Bertolli pasta sauces business in North America for approximately US $2.15 billion to Mizkan Group. In Europe we disposed of our meat snacks business to Jack Link’s. We also sold our Royal pasta brand in the Philippines for US $48 million and our Slim. Fast business in the US.
claude3.7: Summary: N/A
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The sale of specific business units like Ragu, Bertolli, and Royal pasta involves individual organizations.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The transactions involve multiple organizations across different sectors, such as Mizkan Group and Jack Link’s.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] The sale of various business units by an organization to other companies represents a direct causal link between organizational and inter-organizational scales.

Full Paragraph Text: In December 2014 we bought Talenti Gelato & Sorbetto in the US. Founded in 2003, Talenti has grown into the best-selling packaged gelato in the US with products made from the finest ingredients, using artisanal methods. Talenti generated sales of more than US $126 million in the year to 31 December 2014. We also committed to acquire the skin cleansing brands Camay, globally, and Zest outside North America and the Caribbean. Our Mexican market position will be a particular beneficiary of these deals.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The text refers to 'we' (likely Unilever or another large company) as a single organization making acquisitions.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The acquisitions of Talenti Gelato & Sorbetto, Camay, and Zest represent inter-organizational transactions where one company is acquiring brands/companies from others.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] A single company's acquisition decisions directly reshape the competitive landscape in multiple product sectors, particularly strengthening their position in the Mexican market.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The acquisition of Talenti Gelato & Sorbetto and the commitment to acquire Camay and Zest are actions taken by a specific organization.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The acquisitions involve interactions between multiple organizations and affect market positions, indicating a sector-level impact.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] The acquisition of Talenti and other brands by an organization influences its market position and sector dynamics.
o4_mini: Scales: Environmental and Societal, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Organizational
o4_mini: Causal Pathway: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Talenti Gelato & Sorbetto is a specific organization that has been acquired.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The acquisition of skin cleansing brands indicates interaction between multiple organizations in the market.; Environmental and Societal: The mention of market position and benefits to the Mexican market suggests broader societal impacts.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] The acquisition of Talenti and skin cleansing brands enhances market position, benefiting the Mexican market.

Full Paragraph Text: We are also taking action to make sure that we get the most out of our core business by making sharper choices within our existing category portfolio and addressing areas of under-performance. For example, we have set a clear target to double our core operating margin in Home Care over the coming years, as this is a category where profitability is relatively low. We also announced a new stand-alone business unit for European and North American spreads, whereturnover has been declining. The new unit, called Baking, Cooking and Spreading, will be fully in place by the middle of 2015. It will bring greater focus, address new growth opportunities, and has a clear objective to stabilise sales while maintaining strong cash delivery.
claude3.7: Summary: N/A
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company is making strategic decisions to improve its core business and profitability.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The creation of a new business unit for European and North American spreads indicates a sector-level strategy to address declining turnover.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] The company is restructuring its business units to address sector-level challenges and improve profitability.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company is making strategic decisions to improve its core business and profitability.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The creation of a new business unit indicates a response to market conditions and competition in the spreads sector.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector] The company's strategic restructuring aims to enhance profitability and address market challenges in the spreads sector.
gemini2.5: Summary: N/A

Full Paragraph Text: In March 2014 Unilever announced the issuance of our first ever green sustainability bond which raised £250 million. The fixed rate notes pay a coupon of 2% and are due for repayment in 2018. The proceeds are being deployed on projects which support the achievement of the goals of the USLP in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, water usage and production of waste.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company issuing a green sustainability bond; Environmental and Societal: Capital markets (where the bond is issued) and environmental impacts (greenhouse gas emissions, water usage, waste production)
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's issuance of a green sustainability bond directs capital market funds toward environmental impact projects that reduce greenhouse gas emissions, water usage, and waste production.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as a company, is issuing the green sustainability bond.; Environmental and Societal: The bond proceeds are used for projects aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, water usage, and waste production, which are societal-level environmental goals.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's issuance of a green sustainability bond funds projects that aim to reduce environmental impacts.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever, as an organization, is issuing a green sustainability bond to fund specific projects.; Environmental and Societal: The projects funded by the bond aim to achieve broader environmental goals, impacting societal systems.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's issuance of a green bond directly funds projects aimed at reducing environmental impacts.
gemini2.5: Causal Pathway: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is identified as a single organization issuing the bond and deploying its proceeds.; Environmental and Societal: The 'green sustainability bond' interacts with 'capital markets' (a societal system) to raise funds. The 'projects' supported by the bond aim to reduce 'greenhouse gas emissions, water usage and production of waste,' which represent impacts on 'natural systems' (a component of the Environmental and Societal scale).
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever, an organizational entity, issued a green bond drawing funds from capital markets, which are then deployed by Unilever to fund projects aimed at reducing environmental impacts.

Full Paragraph Text: In India around 600 million people, like Saritadevi (pictured*), do not have access to a toilet in their house, leaving them no choice but to use local fields. Unilever is committed to helping 25 million people gain improved access to a toilet by 2020, by promoting the benefits of using clean toilets and making toilets accessible.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Individual: Saritadevi and the 600 million people in India who lack access to toilets; Organizational: Unilever as a company with a specific commitment to help 25 million people; Environmental and Societal: The broader societal issue in India affecting 600 million people and their sanitation infrastructure
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's commitment to help 25 million people gain improved access to toilets by 2020 aims to address a large-scale societal sanitation issue affecting 600 million people in India.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Individuals like Saritadevi who lack access to toilets.; Organizational: Unilever, a company working to improve toilet access.; Environmental and Societal: The societal issue of sanitation affecting millions in India.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's efforts aim to improve sanitation access for millions in India.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Individual: Saritadevi represents individuals lacking access to sanitation.; Organizational: Unilever is an organization working to improve sanitation access.; Environmental and Societal: The issue of sanitation affects broader societal health and environmental conditions.
o4_mini: Summary: [Individual -> Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] Unilever's initiative aims to improve sanitation access for individuals like Saritadevi, impacting societal health and environmental conditions.
gemini2.5: Causal Pathway: Individual -> Environmental and Societal; Organizational -> Individual; Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'Saritadevi', '600 million people', and '25 million people', representing specific individuals or large groups of people directly affected or targeted.; Organizational: Refers to 'Unilever', a single company acting to address a societal issue.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'local fields' (representing natural systems impacted by human activity) and the broader context of 'access to a toilet' and 'clean toilets' (representing societal infrastructure, public health, and community well-being).
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual -> Environmental and Societal; Organizational -> Individual; Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] The lack of household toilets for individuals leads to the use of local fields, creating an environmental and societal problem, which Unilever (an organization) is addressing by improving toilet access for individuals and promoting better sanitation practices.

Full Paragraph Text: We are working with multiple partners, including UNICEF, to create sustainable approaches to better sanitation by promoting good hygiene practices to improve the health and well-being of communities and helping to create demand for access to toilets.

claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The 'we' refers to a single organization working on sanitation initiatives.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Multiple partners including UNICEF collaborating on sanitation approaches represents inter-organizational collaboration.; Environmental and Societal: Communities whose health, well-being, and sanitation practices are being influenced represent the societal scale.
claude3.7: Summary: [Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal] A collaborative partnership between multiple organizations including UNICEF is working to influence community health outcomes through promoting hygiene practices and creating demand for improved sanitation.
4o: Scale Explanations: Inter-Organizational / Sector: The involvement of multiple partners, including UNICEF, indicates collaboration across organizations.; Environmental and Societal: The focus on improving the health and well-being of communities and creating demand for sanitation facilities impacts societal-level systems.

Full Paragraph Text: We are also working with Water & Sanitation for the Urban Poor (WSUP) to develop innovative sanitation businesses and promote hygiene communications to millions of the poorest consumers in Ghana, Bangladesh, Kenya and Zambia.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is working with WSUP (Water & Sanitation for the Urban Poor), which is a specific organization.; Individual: The 'poorest consumers' in Ghana, Bangladesh, Kenya and Zambia represent individuals at the personal scale.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual] Organizations (Unilever and WSUP) are developing sanitation businesses and hygiene communications that directly impact millions of individual poor consumers across multiple countries.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: WSUP is an organization working to develop sanitation businesses.; Environmental and Societal: The initiative targets societal-level systems by promoting hygiene communications to millions of consumers in multiple countries.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] WSUP's initiatives aim to improve sanitation and hygiene for millions in several countries.
o4_mini: Scale Explanations: Organizational: WSUP is an organization focused on developing sanitation businesses.; Environmental and Societal: The initiative aims to impact the hygiene and sanitation conditions of poor consumers in multiple countries.
o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Environmental and Societal] WSUP's efforts to develop sanitation businesses aim to improve hygiene for the poorest consumers in Ghana, Bangladesh, Kenya, and Zambia.

The 'innovative sanitation businesses' being developed also fall under the Organizational scale as new formal entities.; Individual: 'millions of the poorest consumers' represents a large group of specific individuals who are the direct recipients of hygiene communications.; Environmental and Societal: The countries 'Ghana, Bangladesh, Kenya and Zambia' represent societal-level systems, including their communities, public health, and infrastructure, which are the ultimate beneficiaries and contexts of these efforts.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] An organization develops sanitation businesses and promotes hygiene communications to individuals, with the aim of improving sanitation and public health at the societal level in various countries.

Full Paragraph Text: And we are providing support through the Domestos Toilet Academy, a market-based model that improves sanitation in India and Vietnam. By the end of 2014 there were ten Domestos Toilet Academies open, eight in India and two in Vietnam. The Academies train entrepreneurs to form businesses supplying, installing and maintaining hygienic toilets. The initiative will train 250 entrepreneurs and supply 51,000 toilets by the end of 2015.
claude3.7: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Domestos Toilet Academy is a specific organization/program running the initiative.; Individual: Entrepreneurs being trained to form businesses represent individuals receiving training and support.; Environmental and Societal: The improved sanitation in India and Vietnam represents a societal-level impact.
claude3.7: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] The Domestos Toilet Academy (organizational) trains individual entrepreneurs who then create businesses that improve sanitation access at the societal level in India and Vietnam.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The Domestos Toilet Academy is an initiative by an organization.; Individual: Entrepreneurs are individuals being trained by the academy.; Environmental and Societal: The initiative aims to improve sanitation, a societal-level concern.
4o: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] The Domestos Toilet Academy trains entrepreneurs to improve sanitation in India and Vietnam.

o4_mini: Summary: [Organizational -> Individual -> Environmental and Societal] The Domestos Toilet Academy trains entrepreneurs to improve sanitation, impacting public health in India and Vietnam.
